This is a classic black swan. A lot of Brier scores - including mine - will suffer for this, but what the heck? There is no way any forecaster could have predicted the sequence of events that led to the closure of this IFP as a "Yes." My rationale for forecasting zero probability was that I thought it unlikely that any country would want to publicize a successful cyber attack, and therefore would more probably retaliate in kind. In this instance however, where domestic politics are arguably more important than international ones, it's actually advantageous to the Democrats to taint Trump's win and publicize the idea that the hacking was by Russian intelligence.  The hacking of DNC and Podesta *by the Russians* has ever never been established. There's also a theory that the DNC emails, at least, were leaked by disgruntled Sander supporters. So someone released the emails, we just - so far - don't know who. The CIA's explanation of the matter is mostly conjecture and opinion. But as a matter of Democrats vs. Republicans - not Americans vs. Russians -  the accusation of foreign hacking and publicly announced sanctions makes perfect sense.

Levine, Cloherty, Keneally and Parkinson (2016) December 29, state that: President Obama has expelled 35 Russian intelligence operatives and sanctioned five Russian entities and four individuals for an alleged cyberassault on Democratic political organizations during the 2016 presidential campaign, the White House announced today.
“I have ordered a number of actions in response to the Russian government’s aggressive harassment of U.S. officials and cyber-operations aimed at the U.S. election,” Obama wrote in a statement. “These actions follow repeated private and public warnings that we have issued to the Russian government and are a necessary and appropriate response to efforts to harm U.S. interests in violation of established international norms of behavior.”
He said all Americans “should be alarmed by Russia’s actions,” which were designed to “interfere with the U.S. election process.”
“These data theft and disclosure activities could only have been directed by the highest levels of the Russian government,” Obama said. “Moreover, our diplomats have experienced an unacceptable level of harassment in Moscow by Russian security services and police over the last year. Such activities have consequences.”
Kremlin spokesman Dimitry Peskov said the sanctions are intended to “spoil” U.S. relations with Russia and “undermine” the incoming Trump administration, according to Russian news agency Interfax.
Obama issued an executive order, amending his April 2015 decree to expand authorization for a response to certain cyberactivity that seeks to interfere with or undermine U.S. election processes and institutions.
Obama said that the State Department is also shutting down two Russian compounds, in Maryland and New York, used by Russian personnel for intelligence-related purposes, and has ordered 35 Russian intelligence operatives to leave the U.S. within 72 hours.
State Department deputy spokesman Mark Toner wrote in a statement, “The Russian government has impeded our diplomatic operations by, among other actions: forcing the closure of 28 American corners which hosted cultural programs and English-language teaching; blocking our efforts to begin the construction of a new, safer facility for our consulate general in St. Petersburg; and rejecting requests to improve perimeter security at the current, outdated facility in St. Petersburg” (para 1-9). Statement by the President on Actions in Response to Russian Malicious Cyber Activity and Harassment
Department of State (2016) December 29, states that: Today, I have ordered a number of actions in response to the Russian government’s aggressive harassment of U.S. officials and cyber operations aimed at the U.S. election. These actions follow repeated private and public warnings that we have issued to the Russian government, and are a necessary and appropriate response to efforts to harm U.S. interests in violation of established international norms of behavior.
All Americans should be alarmed by Russia’s actions. In October, my Administration publicized our assessment that Russia took actions intended to interfere with the U.S. election process.  These data theft and disclosure activities could only have been directed by the highest levels of the Russian government. Moreover, our diplomats have experienced an unacceptable level of harassment in Moscow by Russian security services and police over the last year.  Such activities have consequences.  Today, I have ordered a number of actions in response.
I have issued an executive order that provides additional authority for responding to certain cyber activity that seeks to interfere with or undermine our election processes and institutions, or those of our allies or partners.  Using this new authority, I have sanctioned nine entities and individuals:  the GRU and the FSB, two Russian intelligence services; four individual officers of the GRU; and three companies that provided material support to the GRU’s cyber operations.  In addition, the Secretary of the Treasury is designating two Russian individuals for using cyber-enabled means to cause misappropriation of funds and personal identifying information.  The State Department is also shutting down two Russian compounds, in Maryland and New York, used by Russian personnel for intelligence-related purposes, and is declaring “persona non grata” 35 Russian intelligence operatives.  Finally, the Department of Homeland Security and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are releasing declassified technical information on Russian civilian and military intelligence service cyber activity, to help network defenders in the United States and abroad identify, detect, and disrupt Russia’s global campaign of malicious cyber activities.
These actions are not the sum total of our response to Russia’s aggressive activities. We will continue to take a variety of actions at a time and place of our choosing, some of which will not be publicized. In addition to holding Russia accountable for what it has done, the United States and friends and allies around the world must work together to oppose Russia’s efforts to undermine established international norms of behavior, and interfere with democratic governance. To that end, my Administration will be providing a report to Congress in the coming days about Russia’s efforts to interfere in our election, as well as malicious cyber activity related to our election cycle in previous elections.  Department of State Website. (2016). Statement by the President on Actions in Response to Russian Malicious Cyber Activity and Harassment. The White House. Office of the Press Secretary. Mason and Wroughton (2016), Dec 29, state that: Obama said the State Department declared as "persona non grata" 35 Russian intelligence operatives and is closing two Russian compounds in New York and Maryland that were used by Russian personnel for "intelligence-related purposes". The State Department originally said the 35 were diplomats (para. 9).
A senior U.S. official told Reuters the move would affect the Russian embassy in Washington and consulate in San Francisco.
The Russians have 72 hours to leave the United States, the official said. Access to the two compounds, which are used by Russian officials for intelligence gathering, will be denied to all Russian officials as of noon on Friday, the senior U.S. official added. *****
"These actions were taken to respond to Russian harassment of American diplomats and actions by the diplomats that we have assessed to be not consistent with diplomatic practice," the official said.
The State Department has long complained that Russian security agents and traffic police have harassed U.S. diplomats in Moscow, and U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry has raised the issue with Putin and his foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov. ***** "By imposing costs on the Russian diplomats in the United States, by denying them access to the two facilities, we hope the Russian government reevaluates its own actions, which have impeded the ability and safety of our own embassy personnel in Russia," the official said.
The U.S. official declined to name the Russian diplomats who would be affected, although it is understood that Russia's ambassador to the United States, Sergei Kislyak, will not be one of those expelled (para. 9-15). U S set to announce response to Russian election hacking sources Volz and Schectman (2016) Wed Dec 28, states that; WASHINGTON The Obama administration plans to announce on Thursday a series of retaliatory measures against Russia for hacking into U.S. political institutions and individuals and leaking information in an effort to help President-elect Donald Trump and other Republican candidates, two U.S. officials said on Wednesday.
Both officials declined to specify what actions President Barack Obama has approved, but said targeted economic sanctions, indictments, leaking information to embarrass Russian officials or oligarchs, and restrictions on Russian diplomats in the United States are among steps that have been discussed.
One decision that has been made, they said, speaking on the condition of anonymity, is to avoid any moves that exceed the Russian election hacking and risk an escalating cyber conflict that could spiral out of control. One example of an excessive step might be interfering with Russian internet messaging (para 1-3). In past cases, administration officials have decided to publicly blame North Korea and indict members of China’s military for hacking because they decided the net benefit of public shaming – and increased awareness brought to cyber security – outweighed potential risks (para. 13).
In past cases, administration officials have decided to publicly blame North Korea and indict members of China’s military for hacking because they decided the net benefit of public shaming – and increased awareness brought to cyber security – outweighed potential risks (para. 13). But determining an appropriate response to Russia's actions has proven more complicated in part because Russia's cyber capabilities are more advanced and due to fears about disrupting other geopolitical issues, such as the civil war in Syria. Obama may choose to invoke an April 2015 executive order that empowered him to levy sanctions in response to cyber-attacks perpetrated by foreign groups targeting infrastructure, such as transportation, or done for economic purposes. [One option, said a U.S. government official who has participated in discussions on possible retaliation, would be leaking material on Russian officials or actions that the United States already has obtained in a way that would “parallel what the Russians did, but be impossible to prove”]. The U S is no stranger to interfering in the elections of other countries Agrawal (2016) December 21, states that: The CIA has accused Russia of interfering in the 2016 presidential election by hacking into Democratic and Republican computer networks and selectively releasing emails. But critics might point out the U.S. has done similar things. 
The U.S. has a long history of attempting to influence presidential elections in other countries – it’s done so as many as 81 times between 1946 and 2000, according to a database amassed by political scientist Dov Levin of Carnegie Mellon University.
That number doesn’t include military coups and regime change efforts following the election of candidates the U.S. didn’t like, notably those in Iran, Guatemala and Chile. Nor does it include general assistance with the electoral process, such as election monitoring.
Levin defines intervention as “a costly act which is designed to determine the election results [in favor of] one of the two sides.” These acts, carried out in secret two-thirds of the time, include funding the election campaigns of specific parties, disseminating misinformation or propaganda, training locals of only one side in various campaigning or get-out-the-vote techniques, helping one side design their campaign materials, making public pronouncements or threats in favor of or against a candidate, and providing or withdrawing foreign aid.
In 59% of these cases, the side that received assistance came to power, although Levin estimates the average effect of “partisan electoral interventions” to be only about a 3% increase in vote share.
The U.S. hasn’t been the only one trying to interfere in other countries’ elections, according to Levin’s data. Russia attempted to sway 36 foreign elections from the end of World War II to the turn of the century – meaning that, in total, at least one of the two great powers of the 20th century intervened in about 1 of every 9 competitive, national-level executive elections in that time period (para. 1-6). Agrawal, N. (2016). The U.S. is no stranger to interfering in the elections of other countries. The Los Angeles Times. Retrieved from
http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-us-intervention-foreign-elections-20161213-story.html

Clips from Post article: 
"What is one of the biggest public misperceptions of the CIA?
The agency obviously operates largely in secret. From that flows the biggest misperception, which is that we operate outside of oversight, outside of legal and policy constraints. The reality is that we have extensive interaction with Congress, particularly with our oversight committees in the House and the Senate. We are on a daily basis sending written congressional notifications about significant intelligence activities—things we’ve done well, things that have gone badly and new initiatives that we are undertaking. There also is a misperception that we dream up covert action programs and execute them outside of any tether to the rest of the administration, which is just not true. Covert action programs are the president’s programs. They start with a presidential finding that defines the objective and the authorities we can employ. There is a lot of back and forth about the operation of covert action with the president and the president’s staff." The Cipher Brief, December 4, 'An Open Letter to the CIA Director Nominee': https://www.thecipherbrief.com/column/agenda-setter/open-letter-cia-director-nominee-1091
Clips from the Cipher article:
"You must refocus the Agency on what makes it unique and codified in Executive Order 12333:  the aggressive, clandestine collection of intelligence.  The CIA must not be the intelligence version of the Salvation Army bell ringer, where we stand and wait for information to be deposited into the kettle for subsequent analysis.  The operational role of CIA is unique in the U.S. Government, and as former colleague and Cipher Brief Network member, John Sipher said, some information may never be given nor shared, and we must use the tradecraft of espionage to acquire it in order to inform policy.  You will have to assess whether the homogenization and pasteurization of functions under Modernization has eroded this nationally-critical ethos.   I believe it is possible we have dulled the edge on our operational knife, and you must return clandestine operations to its position as a top priority for the entire Agency.   The Agency must do a better job at collaboration and cooperation within the IC and with other agencies, departments, and institutions important to the Agency’s mission. I recommend you pay particular attention to the Agency’s relationships with the operational and intelligence organizations of the Department of Defense.  As the scale of major combat shrinks, the opportunities for DoD civilians and warriors to serve together with a shared mission will also shrink.  Shrinking with it will be the instinct to cooperate and collaborate, which will be necessary as CIA and DoD elements operate together across the globe.  You should also look at whether CIA has the right relationships with academia, think tanks, and the national laboratories.  As I stated earlier, the magic of CIA comes from the magicians not the institution.  To grow this magic, CIA must have a diverse workforce in order to be relevant and effective.  The current Agency leadership has put a priority on diversity for its leadership, followership, and recruiting of talent from across the nation, which has set the example within the IC and the U.S. Government.  You must continue this momentum and invest in every opportunity to acquire the diverse skills, talent, imagination that the Agency will need to face the challenges of the future. There is another sensitive issue within CIA and that is its dependence on contractors.  Since 9/11, CIA has seen a necessary growth in the number of contractors it has needed to perform functions as diverse as the functions within the Agency itself; we had no choice as we had a critical mission to do, and we needed the capability to do it. In the spirit of full disclosure, I have been extremely well served in all four of the stations I have had the honor to be the Chief.  Contractors have not only provided critical operational, technical and support services to my stations but many of my contractors were former senior members of the Directorate of Operations and their mentorship, coaching and wise counsel served me exceptionally well.  That said, it will be enlightening and useful for you to ask for an inventory of the contractor workforce within the Agency.  In the aggregate, you will find they are the “hidden directorate” and comprise a significant portion of the overall workforce.  What this should tell you is a story not of fraud/waste/abuse, but a clear message that the Agency remains dangerously too small for the mission it has been given.  CIA will need your Congressional experience and relationships on the Hill to help grow the number of employees to better match the mission obligations. I'm downgrading my forecast significantly given the time left in the year and the fact that there will soon be a new US President.  The reason I am still not wiling to go down much lower, in line with the median on this question, is that Obama said today that the US "will retaliate" (https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/dec/16/obama-retaliation-russia-hacking-us-election). That is a very strong statement. Further, since it is unclear what, if anything, Trump would be willing to do, there is still a chance that Obama will take it on himself; he's made a number of big moves in the last year as he tries to leave his mark. I don't think it is impossible that he would do something in the coming weeks.  Conversely, sanctions take significant political weight. The US is very divided, even on this hacking issue, and Obama may not get the support to impose sanctions on Russia in the coming weeks. It is more likely that "retaliation" will be something more covert, something that Trump may not even realize is happening if he continues to ignore his intelligence briefings; this would be something Obama could make happen without political support.  Note, also, that this question isn't limited to just the US/Russia affair. Although that is currently top of mind, the world is moving fast and there are European countries that would likely act quickly if cyber espionage was uncovered. I have no reason to think anything is going on, but after the past year's events I know things can move very quickly and unexpectedly.

Lipton, Sanger and Shane (2016) December 13, states that: WASHINGTON — When Special Agent Adrian Hawkins of the Federal Bureau of Investigation called the Democratic National Committee in September 2015 to pass along some troubling news about its computer network, he was transferred, naturally, to the help desk.
His message was brief, if alarming. At least one computer system belonging to the D.N.C. had been compromised by hackers federal investigators had named “the Dukes,” a cyberespionage team linked to the Russian government.
The F.B.I. knew it well: The bureau had spent the last few years trying to kick the Dukes out of the unclassified email systems of the White House, the State Department and even the Joint Chiefs of Staff, one of the government’s best-protected networks.
Yared Tamene, the tech-support contractor at the D.N.C. who fielded the call, was no expert in cyberattacks. His first moves were to check Google for “the Dukes” and conduct a cursory search of the D.N.C. computer system logs to look for hints of such a cyber intrusion. By his own account, he did not look too hard even after Special Agent Hawkins called back repeatedly over the next several weeks — in part because he wasn’t certain the caller was a real F.B.I. agent and not an impostor.
“I had no way of differentiating the call I just received from a prank call,” Mr. Tamene wrote in an internal memo, obtained by The New York Times, that detailed his contact with the F.B.I.
It was the cryptic first sign of a cyberespionage and information-warfare campaign devised to disrupt the 2016 presidential election, the first such attempt by a foreign power in American history. What started as an information-gathering operation, intelligence officials believe, ultimately morphed into an effort to harm one candidate, Hillary Clinton, and tip the election to her opponent, Donald J. Trump (para. 1-6). Lipton, E., Sanger, D., E. & Shane, S. (2016). How Moscow Aimed a Perfect Weapon at the U.S. Election. The New York Times. Politics. Retrieved from

Destructive Hacks Strike Saudi Arabia Challenging Trump Riley, Carey and Fraher (2016) December 1, state that: State-sponsored hackers have conducted a series of destructive attacks on Saudi Arabia over the last two weeks, erasing data and wreaking havoc in the computer banks of the agency running the country’s airports and hitting five additional targets, according to two people familiar with an investigation into the breach.
Saudi Arabia said after inquiries from Bloomberg News that “several” government agencies were targeted in attacks that came from outside the kingdom, according to state media. No further details were provided. 
Although a probe by Saudi authorities is still in its early stages, the people said digital evidence suggests the attacks emanated from Iran. That could present President-elect Donald Trump with a major national security challenge as he steps into the Oval Office.
The use of offensive cyber weapons by a nation is relatively rare and the scale of the latest attacks could trigger a tit-for-tat cyber war in a region where capabilities have mushroomed ever since an attack on Saudi Aramco in 2012.
Unlike the Aramco attack or the one by North Korea against Sony Pictures in 2014, the latest was perpetrated by detonating a cyber weapon inside the networks of several targets at once, the people said. Concerns over a broader campaign set off a search in computer networks throughout the Gulf for more traces of the digital bomb.
No one was available to comment at the Iranian foreign ministry or at the Iranian presidency’s media relations department. Wednesday was a public holiday and Thursday is the start of the Iranian week-end (para 1-6). Riley, M., Carey, G. & Fraher, J. (2016). Destructive Hacks Strike Saudi Arabia, Challenging Trump. Bloomberg. Markets. Retrieved from

Time to lament what I got wrong here: 
Questioned opened up 15 Dec 2015.  At that point, cyber was not in any specific countries sanctions list, though was a coverall E.O.  Sony hack was known and HR757 was in play against NK.  My view was that if 757 became law, if it included a prohibited activity referencing cyber this would count as a sanction.  Well 757 became law, EO 13722 (https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/nk_eo_20160316.pdf) was published March 15, 2016 and this now specifically prohibited transaction with NK due to it having engaged in significant activities undermining cybersecurity.  Fairly summarised here https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/114/hr757/summary, "“It imposes mandatory sanctions on individuals who contribute to North Korea’s nuclear and ballistic missile program, its malicious cyber-attacks, "".    OFAC agrees (https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/nkorea.pdf) that under "E.O. 13722 blocks the property and interests in property of the Government of North Korea and the Workers’ Party of Korea... for ... engaged in significant activities undermining cybersecurity", but prohibited activities it turns out are not sanctions (for this q) and so this didnt count (section V of OFAC seemingly takes a different view, which was my view, but did not to resolve this q).  It seems to be have been successfully argued this is a framework and not an actual sanction, whereby to trigger a yes an individual or organisation in addition to the Government of NK needed to be blocked and added to the Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons (SDN List) to count.  Darn.
So then I patiently waited the 6 months for Obama to report on as per 757, turns out he didnt want to add anyone to the list, probably thinking NK Govt and Workers Party of Korea was enough.  Darn x 2.  
Then feint hope that the sanctions brought in response to the SWIFT attacks (http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/02/world/asia/treasury-imposes-sanctions-on-north-korea.html?_r=0) and  (from 38North: Sergei Shevchenko and Adrian Nish, “Cyber heist attribution,” BAE Systems Threat Research Blog, May 13, 2016, http://baesystemsai.blogspot.co.uk/2016/05/cyber-heist-attribution.html. See also: “SWIFT attacker’s malware linked to more financial attacks”; Symantec Official Blog, May 26, 2016, https://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/swift-attackers-malware-linked-more-financial-attack), but these were deemed sanctions already in prep not in response to, nor the final straw.  Darn x 3.
Overall, went too heavy too quickly and misunderstood it - going to hurt me along with other cyber miss.

Russian Suspected of Hacking U.S. Tech Companies Is Indicted
SAN FRANCISCO — A Russian man accused of breaking into computer systems at three internet companies in 2012 has been indicted by a federal grand jury in Oakland, Calif. Yevgeniy Aleksandrovich Nikulin, 29, was arrested this month while vacationing with his girlfriend in the Czech Republic on charges that he hacked into computer networks at LinkedIn, Dropbox and Formspring, damaged computers and conspired to traffic in stolen information. The arrest of Mr. Nikulin provided a look at the shadowy world of Russian hackers, who appear to operate with relative impunity even as they are accused of escalating attacks on computer networks in the United States. They are accused of attacking a long list of targets, including retailers, banks, energy companies, and more recently, the Democratic National Committee. Hackers have been able to operate in Russia with little concern about getting arrested, security experts and law enforcement executives say, so long as they do not attack targets inside Russian borders. But they risk arrest when they leave the country. In 2014, for example, a hacker was arrested in Guam and extradited to the United States for accessing cash register systems at American retailers between 2009 and 2011. A federal jury convicted that hacker, Roman Valerevich Seleznev, of 38 counts of hacking-related charges in August. He is awaiting sentencing. The grand jury indictment, which was unsealed on Friday, accuses Mr. Nikulin of hacking into the computer networks of the three companies, damaging the computers of LinkedIn and Formspring employees, and using their credentials for further intrusions. He is also accused of conspiring with unnamed co-conspirators to traffic in user credentials stolen from Formspring, a social networking site. He faces three counts of computer intrusion, two counts of causing damage to a protected computer, two counts of aggravated identity theft, one count of trafficking, and one count of conspiracy. Mr. Nikulin could face more than 30 years of prison and more than $1 million in fines. The charges were announced on Friday by Brian J. Stretch, a lawyer at the Justice Department, and John F. Bennett, a special agent in charge with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Nikulin, who goes by the online aliases Chinabig01, Dex.007, Valeriy.krutov3 and itBlackHat, was captured in a raid at a hotel in central Prague on Oct. 5. The arrest came 12 hours after authorities there learned he was in the country with his girlfriend and driving a luxury car, according to local police. He did not resist arrest, but had medical problems and was briefly hospitalized, the police said in a statement. The raid was conducted in collaboration with the F.B.I. after Interpol issued an arrest warrant for him. Mr. Nikulin’s arrest came two days before the Obama administration formally accused the Russian government of stealing and disclosing emails from the Democratic National Committee and other institutions and prominent individuals. Federal officials, including Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., have said that the United States would respond to the Russian attacks in kind. After the Czech police arrested Mr. Nikulin, the Russian Embassy in Prague called for his release. Aleksei Kolmakov, spokesman for the embassy in Prague, was quoted by the state-run Russian news agency Tass as saying, “We insist that the detained Russian citizen should be transferred to Russia.” A judge in Prague ordered Mr. Nikulin to remain in custody and a court to examine whether to extradite him to the United States. Continue reading the main story

https://www.lawfareblog.com/us-cyber-deterrence-strategy-more-russian-roulette "Yesterday’s news that the White House plans to issue a “proportional” but possibly secret response does not actually indicate whether any decision has been reached regarding what sort of response we can expect and when. If anything, the statement indicates a continuation of the same policies. The Administration used nearly identical language when vowing to respond to North Korea’s attack on Sony (where the ultimate visible response was sanctions) and similar terms in pledging to retaliate against the Chinese for the OPM breach (where there was ultimately no visible US response, though China did arrest individuals it claimed were responsible). "It’s easy to be skeptical. Adversary nations continue to engage in significant malicious cyber activity against the United States. The only visible response from the US is a Name and Shame strategy of sanctions and indictments, which is applied sporadically and with mixed results. Name and Shame is purportedly augmented by “proportional” retaliatory cyber operations, but the secrecy and vagueness surrounding those prevent any meaningful assessment, raise questions as to whether adversaries even receive the intended message, and cannot deter outside groups who might be watching. "The unpleasant truth is that each of these episodes raises the spectre that the US still does not know when or how it will respond. Since the fundamental questions of deterrence policy appear to be unanswered, one wonders whether the US has any meaningful strategy at all. Or rather, if we have any strategy beyond playing it by ear.
. . .
"The present conflict again highlights the initial question where to draw the line: when is an attack serious enough to merit a response? There is a great deal of activity that occurs in this realm on a daily basis that does not even warrant the investment of time and resources to figure out who is responsible. The fundamental issue is determining where a given action, or course of conduct, fits on the scale. The timing of the official attribution in this case—more than four months after initial reports of Russian involvement—and the Administration’s own stated policy may offer some hints as to where on that spectrum it places the DNC hacks and electoral system intrusions.
. . .
"Broadly speaking, attempts to interfere with the election qualify as “cyber activity intended to cause significant disruption to the normal functioning of U.S. society or government.” As early as July, intelligence officials had “high confidence” that the Russian government was involved in intrusions into the DNC and other political organizations, which resulted in the leaks of large quantities of internal emails. But the administration elected not to publicly respond or confirm attribution at that time, despite calls from commentators and Congress to provide more specific information. "At the end of August, however, reports emerged that a number of states had detected intrusions into election-related systems—first two and then over a dozen. These revelations have generated significant public anxiety over the security of election systems and, when paired with dangerous campaign rhetoric regarding “rigged” outcomes, have stoked genuine concern that people might not trust the integrity of election outcomes. Election-related systems certainly qualify as part of “key services” to the public and the ability to call an election quickly and decisively is incredibly important to functional democratic transitions. "This new information appears to be the impetus for the Administration’s public statement this week. After all, for at least several months the White House has known, with high confidence, that the Russian Government was behind the DNC hack and leaks. The decision to not publicly respond was not based on a need for additional certainty, and there is no indication additional evidence has emerged. The apparent explanation for the change in position is intrusions into state election systems. That activity, either separately or combined with the prior intrusions, crossed the threshold for a response. "With that in mind, the DHS and ODNI joint statement can be read in two distinct ways; it is both a message to Russia and a distinct reassurance to the American people. For Russia, the US government statement is a clear warning. The US government says it knows the Russian Government “directed” the computer intrusions of US political organizations and is not afraid to say so on the record. This limits Russia’s plausible deniability, and adds the U.S. case to the body of international evidence regarding Russian interference around the world, including intrusions into the German parliament and others. And the US government goes further, specifically indicating the leaks are consistent with Russian “methods and motivations” which are to “interfere with the US election process.” The US is typically hesitant to speculate regarding motivations, which can be difficult to discern and are often mixed. Doing so here offers a subtle warning: we know why you’re doing it (Hint: we can hear you, even where you think we can’t.) And naming “senior-most officials” as the responsible actors lays the groundwork to impose sanctions, pursuant to the recent Executive Order for sanctions against “persons engaging in significant malicious cyber-enabled activities.”
. . . 
"Public attribution is itself a significant government response and elucidates some of the administration’s sensibilities regarding line-drawing. . . .  "Taking a broad view is sensible where Russia undertakes hybrid actions—intrusion into computer systems (malicious cyber activity) combined with the strategic release of documents (information warfare)—as well as larger efforts to undertake many distinct activities to achieve an overall goal—to sow distrust in the US electoral system. But the broad view here—where individual “below established threshold activities” combine to cross the threshold—also requires knowing what to group together.
. . . 
". . .  domestic pressures—like the anxiety over election results—figure into the calculations as to whether the US government responds. 
~~~~~~~

Small down tick on my low probability.  Rationale:  Yes, the political environment and tensions seem high but I still believe the effectiveness and impact of primary sanctions is low and certainly wouldn't be any deterrent over the next 30 days (before the election). The big 3 (US, China & Russia) in cyber warfare are very familiar with each other (they hack each other continually - it's the new normal).  The US is the leader and have ways to punish the hacker with offensive actions.  The question is if this situation is worth potentially revealing an advantage that they aren't aware of.  In my opinion, this doesn't come to that level (like when China hacked the OPM in July 2014 and made off with valuable personnel records).  In addition, the US would like to have Russia help with Syria and not cause more trouble in Eastern Europe. Bottom line, annoying, embarrassing, not much value so just talk big and do nothing (it's an election year, we have to respond somehow).

My impression is that the accusations by the White House of the DNC hack and attempts to influence US elections are tit-for-tat. Russia sees that DNC e-mails that they hope will embarrass Clinton are published. White House plays the drama queen by painting Russia's actions as unusual and nefarious in order to damage Trump. Maybe somewhere along the way Congress gets a bee in its bonnet and imposes sanctions. Wait and see.
(no change) It might be time to revisit the whole question of what constitutes sanctions. Would a "sense of the (US) Senate" count?

Haven't looked at this question in a while, so I'm simultaneously updating my estimate regarding some aggressive actions coming out of Iran in March (They did some ineffective DDOS, and nothing seemed to come of it), and updating in response to the recent public accusation of Russia for the DNC attack.  DNC stuff: NYT is a newpaper of record for the US. It's reporting is here, and it's tone and phrasing matters in this highly diplomatic situation: http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/08/us/politics/us-formally-accuses-russia-of-stealing-dnc-emails.html?_r=0 The US doesn't have that great of relations with Russia at the moment, and interference with elections is a pretty major violation of national sovereignty, and there is nothing but election coverage in the US media at the moment, so if currents move toward pointing fingers during the post-Trump RNC soul-searching, there will be enough momentum to follow through with some pretty major policies, including possible sanctions. The end-of-the-year timeframe for the question is going to be pretty significant, because that will give only a little less than two months post-election for the national story to build up to official sanctions, although that story can and has been developing before the official election. (Sanctioning a nuclear power and member of the UN Security Council seems like it would be kind of a big deal, and might distract and/or have unpredictable political consequences if it happens before the election, and I don't think that the generally cautious Clinton would want that, and I don't think that Obama's interests are significantly different from Clinton's. Also, the NYT reported that the administration's current focus is on security the actual polling machines in the states from cyber attacks. Therefore I don't think that the US will sanction Russia before the election.) That being said, the official language that the US is using is "influencing elections", which is pretty explicit, and their statements included a clarification that US election systems are NOT "critical infrastructure", meaning that it does not fit into a category for which the US has vaguely threatened nuclear retaliation (http://defense-update.com/20130628_dempsey_threatens_responding_cyberattack_by_military_action.html - I thought that I remembered something more explicit, but I can't find any references.) So, from an international relations point of view, I think that sanctions are imminent. Furthermore, I think that the news cycle is going to go pretty quickly into a "What the **** was that?" after the election, and Russia is going to be a major part of that, if for no other reason than it will be a convenient scapegoat for the GOP to try to reclaim itself. Given the build-up that is happening now, and how the news cycle is likely to be timed, I'm placing the possibility of sanctions at pretty high. I'll go so far as to say 65%.  Revisiting the possibility from other threats: I don't think that China will do anything until they see how the Russia scenario plays out, but there is also the Christmas season to consider, and there are large economic interests there which might benefit from some government aid. However, if an attack happens around Christmas, it will take some time for the diplomatic build-up to result in sanctions, so we'll miss the deadline for the question. -> 0.5% The Iran stuff I had at 25% when it initially happened (what can I say, I'm a scardy cat), but due to the passage of time and competition for attention in the domain, I'll lower that to 2%. While the chance of needing to respond to Iran directly is decently low, the US needs to have a fairly strong stance on cybersecurity in general due to how aggressive Iran has been in the domain. Part of that strength has already been established, as it successfully withstood an Iranian DDOS attack (with unofficial attribution to Iran) and the official attribution of the Russian attack, as it not only demonstrates the ability of the US to attribute cyber attacks, but it also generically testifies to the US intelligence capabilities and its generic ability to monitor the Iran nuclear deal. However, especially because of the cyber-centric high-stakes relations with Iran, the US also needs to establish its resolve in pursuing cyber sovereignty. That means that Russia isn't going to be able to get away with weaker forms of saying "I'm sorry" to avoid escalation to sanctions. I'll add another 10% to the chance of sanctioning Russia due to the need to signal to Iran.  North Korea is consistently bat-shit crazy, but they've only got a couple of months to do something insane, and there is plenty of stuff to watch before trying to stir the pot themselves. Also including other random bits of insanity that might happen -> 1% (edited, because I forgot to add the 2% from direct Iranian action)
Total: 78.5%

WSJ (opinion), October 7, 'Obama’s Russia Epiphany - The U.S. blames the Kremlin for attacks on U.S. elections. And then?': http://www.wsj.com/articles/obamas-russia-epiphany-1475881969
Clips from WSJ article:
"The meddling in U.S. elections is another matter. In an unusual joint statement Friday, the Department of Homeland Security and Director of National Intelligence said that “the U.S. Intelligence Community (USIC) is confident that the Russian Government directed the recent compromises of e-mails from US persons and institutions, including from US political organizations.”
The U.S. spooks added that “the Russians have used similar tactics and techniques across Europe and Eurasia,” and that given the “scope and sensitivity” of these efforts “only Russia’s senior-most officials could have authorized these activities.” Senior-most is a euphemism for Mr. Putin.
One question is why the Obama Administration has gone public with this hacking news now. One reason might be to warn Russia against dumping more of the U.S. documents it almost certainly has before Election Day. But then Russia’s hacking habits are hardly new, and Mr. Putin is still harboring the national-security thief Edward Snowden. The timing suggests the White House may also be trying to help Hillary Clinton given her campaign’s portrayal of Donald Trump as a Putin apologist. Sure enough, her campaign issued a statement linking Mr. Trump to the news almost on cue Friday.
A public declaration alone won’t stop the Russians. Mr. Putin has little incentive to cease because he and Russia have never paid a price for their cyber thievery. Now that he’s had an epiphany about the Kremlin, will Mr. Obama continue to let Mr. Putin get away with it?" Comments: WH, DHS and the full IC (through ODNI) go on record. What next? See also @Anneinak October 7 post and comments. In agreement. Up-vote 1. Raising incrementally.

OFAC intends to supplement this part with a more comprehensive set of regulations, which may include additional interpretive and definitional guidance, including regarding ‘‘cyber-enabled’’ )  Also, this executive order is a subset of International Emergency Economic Powers Act

which, at the very least, means it should be used in important cases (emergencies) and perhaps best avoided in merely 'disruptive' cases, (but this is my opinion) yet it is not clear how authorities will differentiate, given the first point. Further, a more solid foundation could be reached if there were more international agreements on this topic, UNSC declarations, or supporting countries also enacted regulations regarding cybersecurity. This is lagging, for a variety of reasons I suppose.

In-Q-Tel
In-Q-Tel is the independent, not-for-profit organization created to bridge the gap between the technology needs of the U.S. Intelligence Community (IC) and emerging commercial innovation. We invest in venture-backed startups developing technologies that provide ready-soon innovation (within 36 months) vital to the IC mission. These technology startups are traditionally outside the reach of the IC; in fact, more than 70 percent of our portfolio companies have never before done business with the government.
As a strategic investor, our model is unique. IQT investments accelerate product development and add mission-critical capabilities with the sole purpose of delivering cutting-edge technologies quickly and efficiently. By focusing on commercial technologies and investing side-by-side with venture firms, we help develop sustainable solutions, using off-the-shelf products instead of custom-built systems. On average, for each dollar that IQT invests in a company, the venture capital community invests more than $11.

Forget Software—Now Hackers Are Exploiting Physics
https://www.wired.com/2016/08/new-form-hacking-breaks-ideas-computers-work/ Very cool article that touches on the information warfare strategy of exploiting assumptions. As we know, valid arguments yield true conclusions only if the premises are true. Trick = make the premises false. My contribution (inspired by Bacon): the most vulnerable portion of an argument (the likely location of a manipulation) is the "critical first abstraction," that which connects physical reality to a particularized generalization. Not only is it that if the correspondence of the first abstraction fails, the entire argument is for crap; but a physical manipulation maintains the coherence of the resulting logic, making it easy to escape detection.

Deconstructing Propaganda FBI Warns of Cyberattacks on State Election Boards I was going to omit any reference to this story until, at the conclusion of reading the following article, I realized my head was just not where it should have been (there had been a violation of expectations). An easy way for you to obtain the same realization might be to simply read the headline of the story and then just skip immediately to the final, concluding, paragraph. Then, ask yourself, if whether, upon accepting the implied conclusion of this last paragraph, you feel comfortable with extending such a rationale ("Whatever. Stuff happens. Nothing to get excited about or to do about it.") to the headline instance ("Threat of U.S. elections being stolen via hacking.").
http://abcnews.go.com/US/fbi-warns-cyberattacks-state-election-boards/story?id=41719997 The author begins with a serious threat to U.S. democracy and leaves the reader with a proffered belief structure vis-a-vis that threat of: Don't bother caring. (As in the classic reflexive control model of moving from Point A to Point X without opposition, the reader is being induced not to care, not to raise a defensive counter-measure.) 1) The author conflates instance types. Hacking email is NOT the same as (potentially) hacking election vote counts. The more rational response to the news is that, like everything else in life, a proper risk-analysis is first required. You feel comfortable in most circumstances in taking some amount of cash from an ATM cash machine. Would you, in the exact same circumstances, feel comfortable in taking your entire life savings out in cash from the ATM? Probably not, and you would change your behavior based on your understanding of the risk of the threat (in this case, the difference in the amount of potential loss). So the author, by first conflating stolen elections with hacked emails, and then hacked emails with cyber attacks in general, takes the reader down a garden path to a highly-risky behavioral recommendation. [NB - The transference in an informational deceptive scheme need not be physical property. It need not even be an asset, it just might be in the form of the foisting of a liability upon you. Or, as in this case, it can even be in the form of foisting increased risk upon you.] 2) If you're rational, you allocate care, diligence, vigilance, etc. to things of high perceived value, things that matter. All cyberattacks are not the same, and the solution to some cyberattacks is not to simply "just not care." The optimal solution to preventing election theft via cyberattack is to use public hand-counting of paper ballots. It is not as fast as electronic balloting, but it is far more secure. Some, who believe that the most fundamental right in a democracy is the franchise of voting, might prefer such an approach to "not caring."

The likelihood that state actors will commit cyber attacks and espionage against the US is 100% (At least two nations employ full-time attack teams against the US), so I'm only going to address the possibility that these attacks will result in sanctions. A second assumption is that for sanctions to be on the table, an attack must be at least partially successful. Total inaction in response to possible Russian and constant Chinese attacks leave this very dubious. Hacks that make headlines are very hard to run, so it looks doubtful that a non-cooperative nation like NK or Iran would manage an attack (and Iran's status mid nuclear deal would add a disincentive in any event). If a poor nation were to pull off a major for-profit penetration, e.g. Nigerian hackers stealing thousands' Personally identifying information, using it to submit phony tax returns, and collecting the cash, I suppose sanctions are imaginable? But the act would so clearly be non-state actors, it feels very hard to believe.  It seems hard to imagine a situation where the U.S. would have an upside to sanctions imposition, since even the announcement would leak data about the success of an attack. This is essentially my strongest bet, since I would only give 0% if I knew something to factually impossible (e.g. will a cyber-attack stop Dick Cheney's heart?)

As the "formal" and "informal" communication structures come crashing together, intelligence officials move from "troubled" to "deeply troubled"
http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/deeply-troubling-ex-ambassador-intelligence-officials-blast-trump-russia-comments-n618276 Trump's request seems to be that the 33,000 missing Clinton emails, if already in the possession of some foreign entity, including Russia. be released to the press, so that they might disprove various public statements she has made. Hayden, ignoring this point (and this is the only point that really matters), twists Trumps' request into an "invitation" to conduct a cyber attack, ignoring that the request presumes the attack was already done. This, from the man that knows the U.S., lacking any invitation, routinely steals every email they can get their hands on from Russian and other foreign politicians, and who personally oversaw the construction of the elaborate system which allows the NSA to do the same to every U.S. citizen. The difference between the two is that the NSA needs to try just a little to capture the Russian emails, whereas with the domestic emails they don't need to try at all because the comprehensive automated system to do so is already in place. Trump is not inviting or encouraging Russian espionage. He is, however, definitely encouraging the sharing of such intelligence with the American public. This is certainly provocative, and is apparently "deeply troubling" to some intelligence professionals. What's really troubling, however, is that American voters might need to rely upon Russian espionage to get information as to the disconnect between the formal and informal Clinton pronouncements. It's a balancing of priorities. Whose interests are more important: Clinton's or those of the public? That this is even a question to these intelligence professionals is what's troubling. If the press asserts that the 33,000 emails are no more than dentist appointments and birthday greetings, fine, case closed. The intelligence professionals need not be concerned, Clinton has already asserted that these 33,000 emails which she deleted were non-sensitive, personal emails. What's the worry? If the movement is to reduce the knowledge gap between formal and informal organizational/communication structures, it seems like we can't allow legal niceties such as claims to privacy or evidentiary exclusion rules to impede public understanding as applied to extraordinarily powerful organizational roles. Some innovative organizational restructuring seems required so as to increase the transparency of certain roles. (The situation is doubly-complicated in that Clinton went "off the reservation" with the private server in the first place, thus breaking the assumption that all emails would be retained within the system outside of the control of the very party potentially most interested in removing any that were derogatory. In this respect, Clinton herself has created the situation that calls for the waiving of otherwise reasonable privacy claims.) If the "press as filter" model, as initiated by Snowden, is all we currently have, it is better to use that than to avoid reducing the gap. I'm coming to think that the knowledge gap is a form of latent chaos. The greater the gap, the more chaos unleashed upon the organization should the gap be revealed. No matter the chaos, however, revelation of the gap seems always preferable, because the gap also represents a constant source of unaccountable harm to the organization. It is possible that if Russia were held to be accountable for the revelation of these emails that the recently announced (created?) "public confidence" sanction condition might apply. It would be so crazy ironic, however, where public confidence in their understanding of reality increased (albeit at the expense of public confidence in Hilary Clinton), and became a sanctionable event. I don't believe justification for such a sanction could be politically sustained; or rather, that the fight to do so would be worth it. --------------
"calling for a foreign power to interfere in our election by unlawfully releasing classified information."
http://foreignpolicy.com/2016/07/27/how-should-the-united-states-respond-to-russias-election-meddling/ This is a crafty but disingenuous argument. Since when is a foreign government subject to U.S. laws relating to release of classified information? It's the Snowden dilemma. What do you do when confronted with a moral decision? The revelation of hypocrisy or the adherence to the rule of law? At what point does it become a no-brainer? Suppose a leaked email revealed, without a doubt, that Clinton was a paid agent of China? Suppose the emails revealed Clinton as a liar, as untrustworthy? Is not that knowledge more important than simple adherence to the law? "Do those who seek to put America First really want or trust the Russians to help them do that?"
http://foreignpolicy.com/2016/07/27/how-should-the-united-states-respond-to-russias-election-meddling/ This is a great question, and I very much hope that people are fully prepared for the majority answer. If we acknowledge that trust is problematic, and set that aside, is this a science question, where right and wrong correspond to reality? Or is it a legal question, where right and wrong definitely do not consistently correspond with a moral judgment, but may correspond to the efficient administration of general justice? I suspect the majority of people would desire the scientific answer. So, in reply to the author, it is indeed a question of right and wrong; scientific right and wrong. When it comes to *knowledge* that allows for the prevention of harm, science is the standard, not law. Clips from XX article:
"Such statements, taken as heresy by Snowden’s ardent fans, are uncontroversial among anyone who understands the secret world of espionage. To anybody acquainted with how Russia’s powerful intelligence services actually operate, the idea that Snowden is their collaborator is no more controversial than stating that the sun rises in the east every morning.
The proper espionage term for Edward Snowden is defector, meaning an employee of an intelligence service who takes up residence in another country whose spies are not friends. Since 1917, every single Western intelligence defector to Moscow has cooperated with the Kremlin, on grounds of quid pro quo. There is no known case of a defector not collaborating with the KGB or its successors. If you want sanctuary, you will tell the Russians everything you know. That is how the spy game works.
Any Russian intelligence officer who wants sanctuary in the United States will be required to collaborate with American spy services, including extended debriefings by multiple intelligence agencies. Are we really supposed to believe that Vladimir Putin, former KGB colonel, is more charitable?
“Of course” Snowden is collaborating with Russian intelligence, explained Oleg Kalugin more than two years ago. A legend in global spy circles, Major General Kalugin is the former head of foreign counterintelligence for the KGB’s elite First Chief Directorate. In the Cold War, Kalugin recruited moles inside American intelligence just like Edward Snowden. He is an expert witness here. Kalugin made clear that Snowden’s new life revolves around the Federal Security Service, Putin’s powerful FSB. “The FSB are now his hosts, and they are taking care of him,” he explained: “Whatever he had access to in his former days at NSA, I believe he shared all of it with the Russians, and they are very grateful.”
To anybody familiar with how Russia works, there can be no doubt that Snowden has been an agent of the Kremlin at least beginning with his arrival in Moscow three years ago. Whether he was recruited by the Russian intelligence before that is likely – as I’ve explained before, it would be highly abnormal for the FSB to grant sanctuary to an American defector they have never met – yet it remains an open question, and a very important one. Whether Snowden has collaborated with the Kremlin since June 2013, however, is not an open question.
Since joining Twitter last year, Snowden has pontificated from Moscow on a wide range of issues. In rare form, he entered the debate regarding the NSA special committee, sending out this remarkable tweet yesterday. (It says: “Whether Maassen is an agent of the SVR or FSB” – that is, Russian intelligence – “cannot currently be verified.”) Challenging the BfV director head-on with a mocking tweet is a strange turn of events in the Snowden saga. It is  unlikely such an event would occur in short-term.  It will be difficult to prove an attack, assuming that a government would admit that an attack got through their defences (which are quickly improving).  Then there is the difficulty of getting economic sanctions in place.

I think sanctions would only be imposed in a case where a cyber attack/espionage is clearly state-sponsored or approved. If a cyber attack were to shut down infrastructure (e.g., a power plant), which tends to be very publicly obvious, then sanctions would probably be imposed; most countries will keep quiet about espionage. So far as I am aware, only Russia, China, Iran and North Korea have this capability and a willingness to use it on a North American or EU country. I doubt that Russia or China would launch such a significant attack / espionage beyond what they already do routinely that North American or EU countries would impose sanctions, given all the other diplomatic complications they have right now. Iran is in a similar position -- they are working their way out of international sanctions and do not appear to want to jeopardize their agreement with the US. That leaves North Korea, which does undertake these activities regularly. However, it's hard to imagine even Kim Jong Un undertaking an attack on physical infrastructure -- that is a fairly dramatic escalation because it is a direct attack with physical effects.

Shamir said that the malware, dubbed Furtim, was “clearly not” made by cybercriminals to make some money but for a government spying operations.

It’s unclear who’s behind this cyberespionage operation, but Shamir said it’s likely a government from Eastern Europe, with a lot of resources and skills. The malware’s developers were very familiar with Windows; they knew it “to the bone,” according to him.
“This was not the work of a kid,” he said. “It was cyberespionage at its best.”

Just for the record, I'm going to reiterate my claim that this question resolved positively long ago, and has failed to do so based on an improper understanding of how sanctions are implemented. In short, a set of claims as to bad actions are codified into a supraset called "national emergency." Then, sanctions (the "penalties") are imposed as against the national emergency. That this is the fundamental logic of sanctions, and not a tit-for-tat logic, is evidenced by the need to continue the proclamations of "national emergency." Else, each (falsely believed) tit-for-tat sanction would be allowed to continue on its own, and continuing proclamations would be unnecessary.

Just became familiar with the details of the Guccifer hacking case. Guccifer was the Romanian hacker who got into Sidney Blumenthal's emails and susequently discovered that Hillary Clinton was using a private email address and email server to conduct businesses as Secretary of State.  Guccifer also famously hacked the accounts of Colin Powell and the Bush family (discovering George Bush's paintings of world leaders).  This hacker was a simple, unemployed taxi driver with a high school education.  In a recent interview with NBC News, the said 100's of people are doing what he was doing --hacking into thousands of computers of US corporations and citizens to steal information and resell it.  (He said he did not hack Hillary or anyone to make a profit but because he thought they were part of the Illuminati group that runs the world and wanted to expose them).  Right.   There are so many hackers just in Romania attacking the US government, corporations and citizens that the FBI had to open a field office in the country just to deal with the issue.   Understandably, this is a separate phenomenon than state sanctioned hacking but it goes to illustrate how common it is in today's world and the market there is for information.  I will lower my forecast slightly because of consensus on this question, but I still think this question has a high probability of resolving as yes.

Once again we are confronted with a sloppily worded question.  I interpret this Q to mean that the sanctioning document, whatever it is, must specifically cite cybermischief--and maybe even a particular instance--as the reason for the sanctions.  A perfectly sensible alternative interpretation is that the sanctions are imposed "in response to" cybermischief but because of the difficulty of proving the source, the sanctioning document gives some other official reason for the sanctions--the recent US legislation allows for several.   The difficulty with this for the scorers is being satisfied that the sanctions are really about the cyberstuff and not about the officially stated justification.  Not sure how they will go about this, but about fifty-three seconds of forethought before posting the question would have alleviated the problem.

Iran Rebuffs U.S. Cyber-Attack Charges for Lack of Evidence
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-26/iran-dismisses-u-s-cyber-attack-charges-for-lack-of-evidence For the U.S. to open the tact of indictments as part of a general foreign relations policy related to cyber attacks is ridiculous and hair-brained, even if they are intended to serve as some basis for future sanctions. The "beauty" of historical sanctions is that they are unilateral actions that have hitherto required no more than presidential "findings." To the extent that the U.S. had the sheer power to level them, and enforce the impositions, is what made sanctions work. What now is to prevent Iran, or anybody else for that matter, from charging U.S. individuals with cyber attacks on them? Despite claims to the contrary, unless you have extraordinarily unusual intelligence, you can never tie a cyber attack to more than a computer interface. That is, even if you know that an attack originated from device A in building B in agency C, you can rarely tie that to individual X without "being there" at that device at that time. Maybe, just maybe, you get such inside information on one-in-ten, one-in-twenty, attacks. That leaves the rest that you do not know, and any (good) judge would throw out such a case without it ever getting to a jury. So, now individual attribution is an open game – just grab some names and assign them to an attack (no one can [usually] know!) – available to anyone to play. Folly. “The United States, which with its cyber attacks against Iran’s peaceful nuclear facilities put millions of innocent Iranians at the risk of a environmental disaster is in no position to accuse citizens of other countries, including those of Iran,” Ansari said.

In the past, countries have not retaliated to cyber attacks with strong opposition. Cyber attacks happen frequently so there is a low likelihood that there will be a sudden resistance all of a sudden.
Slight increase on news of indictments. Targeting individuals is still far from sanctions on a country/government.

For this to happen, there needs to be a cyber attack (implying that someone has the means and motive to cause one), and a country needs to respond. Most cyber attacks pass virtually unnoticed because of security systems, and major ones reveal flaws that will quickly be repaired. The odds of an unprompted major cyber attack are relatively low by themselves. However, based on China's actions against GitHub last year, as well as the attack on Ukraine's power plant, there is still a significant chance of it happening. Based on countries' lack of official responses to cyber attacks in the past, it is unlikely that anyone will impose sanctions because of a cyber attack. The recent UN decision to make cyberdefense an official duty might influence this, but it is still improbable.

In 2016 there has been an uptick in ransomware attacks on increasingly large organizations (http://wbtw.com/2016/02/16/horry-county-schools-approve-paying-computer-virus-ransom-making-payment-problematic/). While initial observations would indicate payoff as the goal of such attacks, it appears to me that these attacks have targeted organizations with resources sufficient to defend themselves but without resources sufficient to go after the perpetrators.  From a programming development standpoint it appears these attacks are more of a test of skill than an actual desire for the payout.  This would indicate a large, probably state-sponsored, organization that is testing out new intrusion methodologies. As such, the prospect of state-sponsored attacks increases the likelihood of charges related to such attacks. Mitigating factors include the political fallout associated with such a charge, as well as the difficulty of a government convincing its citizenry that such an attack occurred and was committed by a particular state actor.

The specific acts which constitute the scope of this national emergency are enumerated in this Order, and by explicit reference, all relevant previous Executive Orders (which are cited). Among these, is the January 2, 2015 Order which included the "cyber-related actions during November and December 2014" (the Sony hack attack) as a finding and constituent element in the national emergency. By reference then, the Sony hack attack is contained within the scope of the current national emergency. This satisfies the "in response to" criteria. Any one of the enumerated actions ordered by Obama constitutes the "imposition" criteria. It is not a trivial distinction to separate imposition from enforcement, so I take it that since they have been ordered they are thereby imposed; and whether they are enforced is irrelevant. For those that might insist upon an element to element correlation, rather than a set to set correlation, I can only ask for you to explain what "in response to" element the imposition of searching Korean vessels or freezing transactions of members of the Workers Party specifically relates to. Whatever model of a sanction you embrace, it must be able to address these impositions. I'm thinking you will find that any model that ties impositions to responses does so only through the entity of national emergency. It may not be satisfactory, but these are what sanctions are; and whatever other model you might maintain needs to address all impositions. I take "imposition" to be the operative verb (requiring obtainment after question initiation), and the "in response to" event a prerequisite. If it is the condition that the prerequisite event must also occur after the question initiation, then that would cause the question to become invalid, since ALL malicious cyber related activities were encapsulated prior to the question and there would never be a need to enumerate a particular attack since then. (The only reason the Sony hack attack was specifically enumerated was that it was included within the national emergency prior to the expansion of the scope of the national emergency to include all North Korean malicious cyber related activities). I'm hoping that you will see that the freezing of all transactions of the North Korean Worker's party (and other such "free floating" impositions) clarifies that impositions are in response to a set of prior actions, including the Sony attack, and that the imposition bit need not, in any way, relate to the realm or domain in which the "in response to" behavior initially took place. And, for those who might continue to believe that "proof" is required, you'll note that no proof is offered for the Sony hack finding. Here's an article by an author who is also struggling with the intuitive notion that sanctions require proof, or that perhaps cyber sanctions are a special sort that require proof. I think he would have been better off with the flat-out conclusion that a problem with sanctions is that they are, in a very real sense, unilateral declarations of war; rather than beating around the bush as to how problematic they are to substantiate.

In order for this to happen, there needs to be a publicly disclosed cyber incident involving a North American or EU state that can be traced to another state, and for relations with that state to be poor enough that sanctions are the next step in degraded relations. US surveillance/espionage is unlikely to produce that result, because the states in question have many other ties that will be strained before it gets to the point of sanctions. (And really, who has ever even spoken about imposing sanctions on the United States?).  Cyber powers outside of the generically western block include Russia, Israel, North Korea, and China. Russian activity is largely criminal rather than state sponsored, and is therefore unlikely to result in sanctions, but I'll add a single percentage point because the Russian State probably has access to the means of a cyber offensive. (1%) Israel is unlikely to target western countries and has the non-sanction consequence of a deteriorating relationship with the US if it does.  There was some movement on issuing further sanctions on North Korea, including a bill introduced in the Senate ordering the president to issue sanctions. However, that bill is likely unconstitutional, and it doesn't seem to be doing much but languishing in committee. (comment thread where this issue was exposed in the GJOpen community - https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/124508, Status of the bill - https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/senate-bill/2144). That being said, there is a history of sanctions being imposed on North Korea in response to a cyber attack, and something similar might happen again. -> 3% China was mentioned in the prompt description for good reason - it has large state sponsored cyber offensive infrastructure, and relations with how it is using it are heating up as China illegally accesses sensitive data and and manipulates critical infrastructure. China uses a fair amount of its cyber abilities to conduct economic espionage - something that was condemned by both sides in the 2015 talks, and an action for which the US threatened sanctions. I find it unlikely that China will completely stop its economic cyber espionage, but it a result of the talks is likely that it will take more efforts in being subtle about it. Furthermore, it would take a serious breach in order for the US to change China's status as a trading partner to anything other than the current "Permanent Normal Trade Relations". So: we have on the table a subtle threat from the US to China regarding an activity that China is almost certainly going to continue engaging in. Will that activity escalate to the point that the US must carry out that subtle threat in the next year? Probably not, but it's a non-zero chance. Let's put it at about 10%.  That gives a total of 14%.

The response - imposition structure of sanctions. Here's another example of the basic response - imposition structure of a complex sanction act. In this case, the response is couched in terms of a "national emergency," which included. among other things, "the existence and risk of the proliferation of weapons-usable fissile material on the Korean Peninsula." These constituent things are those which create the "national emergency." It is the national emergency, and derivatively the constituent things, that are being responded to. (In the case of the recent North Korea Sanctions Act, it was the "crisis," and its derivative constituents, that was being responded to.) The imposition, in the case of these OFAC programs, are "blocked transactions." While there are criteria for entities selected for imposition (e.g., being an official of the Workers’ Party of Korea), these criteria are independent of any criteria that may have been used to identify or attribute the underlying derivative constituent things causing the national emergency. If there is any correlation between these two sets of criteria, it is coincidental, and not necessarily required within the notion of a sanction.
https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/nkorea.pdf Here's another case: Response to "national emergency" (this time with a "finding" of the constituent act of "coercive cyber-related actions"). The transitional sentence from the "response" to the "imposition:" "To address this threat and to take further steps with respect to this national emergency, I hereby order." The impositions then follow, with whatever criteria may be applicable to them.
https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/13687.pdf

It's the same response (set)-imposition (set) pattern in every sanction case I have examined.

If the EU imposes sanctions, no individual member state would have to. While I think that imposition of any coercive act under the recently passed North Korea Sanction Act (or whatever it was called) will do to satisfy this question, I'm also thinking that any action taken by a UN member state under the presumably forthcoming UN Korean sanctions would count as well.
http://nysepost.com/us-proposes-sharp-ramping-up-of-north-korea-sanctions-at-un-137429 I'd also like to point out a typical UN sanction resolution. It is a complex act with two phases structured in the format that I have previously described: The first, a "finding," or in the case of the U.N., a "noting," which is the set of sanctionee acts the imposition of coercive acts by the sanctionor is in response to. The second, the imposition itself, and in the U.N. language, that which countries are "called upon" to do.
http://www.un.org/press/en/2006/sc8792.doc.htm I contend that if the U.N. "notes" that North Korea has engaged in cyber-attacks or cyber-espionage, and "calls upon" member states to impose some action on some North Korean entity, and the member state does so, then that member state will have imposed sanctions on North Korea in response to a cyber-attack or cyber-espionage (done so under the auspices of the U.N.). Quick note on the country versus individual bit. I'm not sure where this stands today, but there was at one time the very explicit understanding that any private entity engaging in international commerce never had any standing other than being an agent of his/her country. So, for example, when country A goes to war with country B, the idea that company X (domiciled in country B) can say, "Hey, we're independent of country B," is considered ridiculous. Company X is confiscated until the end of the war, and maybe it gets returned after. We may have an intuitive notion that individual entities are different that the states, perhaps stronger now than ever, but from an historical perspective it doesn't seem to be that way. The fact that the United States, and perhaps others, operate in the very grey area of war without declared war makes some of these things less obvious.
