This is actually a very good question, from the standpoint of being intellectually challenging. There are a variety of things going on with this question. I'm just going to focus on one particular aspect now, but as I said, there are many cool things going on overall. Some named concepts, like "Initial Public Offering" are names of both processes ("Google's IPO") and events (the actual initial listing of Google shares available for sale on a public exchange). These two things, while obviously related, are not strictly the same thing. For example, "Google's IPO" might include such things as underwriting, the quiet period, etc.; all things involved in the process of getting to that one event of the actual initial listing of shares. In the case of the IPO, the final phase of the process, that actual listing event, is just one of many phases in the IPO process. A "sanction" is similar in that it is a name for a process or activity. The sanction process, unlike an IPO, has just two basic phases: the response phase and the imposition phase. It's a little confusing because "response" is typically something that occurs after something else, but strictly in terms of understanding a sanction, the response phase comes first in a sequential order with the imposition phase invariably subsequent. Another difficulty is that, like an IPO, we often confuse the name of the activity for the name of a phase. Here, we often call the imposition phase the sanction. But we are confusing the generally unnamed phase (the imposition phase) with the name of the activity. Another way to look at a sanction is to consider it as a complex act, comprised of two subsidiary acts, that are related in sequence, purpose, etc., but are independent. The two acts are "response" and "imposition." It may sound unreasonable to you, but it is my personal experience that people have an extremely difficult time is managing their understandings as to complex acts. We're very good at discerning each individual act, but since the connection between the two acts is generally "in the mind" of another person, we are usually very crappy in managing our understanding of complex acts performed by others. Of all complex acts, a "sanction" is one of the easier ones to understand because there are only two constituent acts, and these acts are always sequentially related in the same sequence. Another way to think of a complex act is as a single act (which it is) with two phases. With a sanction-act, there are two discrete phases, always related in the same sequential fashion: response and imposition. So while complex acts in general are typically hard for people to manage, as far as complex acts go, "sanction" is one of the easiest: just two phases, always in the same sequential order. "Fraud" is an example of a complex act that is far more challenging to conceptually manage. While fraud consists of three phases (deception, theft, and conversion), the phases need not be discrete, and they need not occur in the same (i.e., normal) sequence, and the conversion phase need not occur at all. All this to try to assist you in getting your head around the notion that a "sanction" consists of two discrete independent phases (response and imposition). I've wasted enough of your time already on a theoretical approach to understanding sanctions. Here's some real live stuff: A couple of weeks ago @Mos was kind enough to provide a video link that pertained to North Korean sanctions: https://foreignaffairs.house.gov/hearing/subcommittee-hearing-us-response-north-korea-s-nuclear-provocations . It's a long video, but it did help me a lot in gaining my perspective on exactly what sanctions are. That is, what is really meant when someone on Capital Hill speaks of a sanction. (You'll also see why China is so crucial to a successful North Korean sanction program.) Also, here's a link to the original Sony hack sanction: http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-30670884 . Here you will see that those upon whom the coercive measures were imposed (imposition) were not the actors that did the deed (in response to). Whatever understanding of "sanction" you come up with, I suggest, has got to meet all the nuances of these two real world examples. You have to "operationalize" a definition, so to speak, so that it can contain every instance of a (current political) "sanction" that you can possibly throw at it. If there's a difficulty with an instance, don't discard the instance and say it wasn't a sanction or whatever, operationalize your definition to accommodate it.

Old but relevant article:
Sony cyber-attack: North Korea calls US sanctions hostile
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-30670884 This articles uses some terms, phrases, and concepts relevant to our question here:
- "imposed in response"
- "the US has moved to punish any country for cyber-attacks on a US company"
- "the move was in response to the Sony hack, but the targets of the sanctions were not directly involved" <-- IMPORTANT Please take a few seconds to consider the third point above. For an understanding of sanctions, it is really important that you understand how this can be the case. Sanctions are penalties on behaviors (xyz) that are not necessarily associated with those behaviors that inspired the sanctions (abc). That is, the "imposition" and the "in response to" are independent sets. This is what sanctions are. The behaviors that inspired the sanctions (for which the sanctions are in response) have already been done and have been identified as such (along with a number of other behaviors). The requirement that sanctions be "actually imposed for a cyber attack or cyber espionage," therefore, may be the GJ standard, but it is misleading as to how sanctions are in fact employed in international law. The "actual" cyber-attack has already occurred. All that is required now is for the imposition of a sanction. And, as I said previously, any sanction under the Law would do. (Whatever "instinct" for fairness or tying the two (independent) sets together you may have, you need to recognize that this is not how sanctions are in fact used. General Kung Park is going to have his assets frozen, and he may have no connection whatsoever to any of the (bad) behaviors enumerated under the North Korea Sanctions Act as those creating a "crisis" to which the Act responds. Yet, he will be sanctioned under that act. The "actual" (bad) behavior is independent of the behavior upon which the penalty is assessed. That is the nature of sanctions. ["the targets of the sanctions were not (may not be) directly involved"] Edit: It's really good to have this understanding of how sanctions are actually employed, so that whenever you hear the word "sanction" you do indeed need to consider the very real possibility that penalties will befall individuals and entities that are wholly "innocent" as to the originating underlying bad acts. You can think of sanctions as you wish, perhaps as a form of coercion against future behavior rather than a penalty for past behaviors. But whatever you think, you should recognize that the act(s) to which they are in response are only coincidentally, if at all, correlated with the behaviors that are punished. They are very handy tools then, for those who are inclined to use them, to apply political and economic pressure in all sorts of ways. Edit2: The teacher returns to the class and says: "Students, upon my return from the hallway where I was speaking with Principal Jones, I find (nb-"finding") the class pet out of her cage, the sink running unattended, and many of you out of your seats. As a result, I am going to impose an after school detention upon the entire class." The set of bad behaviors are independent of the punishment. Is Mary Jane innocent? Maybe. Did Mary Jane get sanctioned for the fact that the class pet got loose? Yes. That is what sanctions are. Sometimes they are "targeted" in ways where guilt correlates more closely with punishment. Sometimes they are not. Sometimes they are just "targeted" be be more effective at placing coercive pressure on certain actors. Was the teacher "fair?" Probably not. So we also see that sanctions involve the use of an enforcement power that is (or may be) divorced from moral legitimacy. Edit3: The above is actually a crappy example, because it's fashioned more as a punishment than as coercion against future behavior. How about "until I can leave and return to the classroom and find you sitting in your seats and doing your assignments, we will do without the morning recess," or something like that. Maybe you can make up your own example.

I read the recent  announcement: 2/19/16: GJ is aware that President Obama recently signed legislation that involves sanctions against North Korea. The question team is consulting with subject matter experts to assess whether this legislation mandates sanctions for cyber activity or merely gives the President discretionary authority to, in the future, sanction North Korea for cyber activity. An announcement will be made once a decision is reached.  Just to add a comment: it might be very hard to resolve the question with the mandatory vs. discretionary issue.  It isn't constitutional for Congress to mandate that the president use his executive authority, and in a way, the wording of the bill recognizes this fact with doubletalk. The bill "mandates" that the president "shall" designate individuals to sanction (for cyber), but only those "that [he] the President determines" have violated a certain criteria. So, the president both has and doesn't have discretion here? The president also has the authority in the bill to determine how he wants to sanction someone.  Congress can't force the president to do anything (and it looks like the wording in the bill is talking out of both sides of it's mouth). It's like if Congress passed a bill mandating that the president "will appoint" the best qualified next Supreme Court Justice based upon A. B. and C. criteria (but only if he determines/interprets that he meets A. B. and C. criteria.) "(a) Mandatory designations.—Except as provided in section 208, the President shall designate under this subsection any person that the President determines— " So the bill says that cyber sanction are in the future mandatory, while also saying that he is able to determine himself if a cyber violation occurs.   In the end a sanction is not a sanction unless it is actually in effect. I admit that this question should close as a yes if the President designates an offender for cyber, but until it happens I can't see the question closing as yes.  Obama has 90 days to either do this or not, and I'm very curious to see if he will. Obama signed the bill and remained silent afterwards. http://dailycaller.com/2016/02/19/americas-incoherent-sanctions-policy/ I post this (generally irrelevant to the question) link not only because it makes a cogent argument, but to point out to those that desire a strong connection between the "bad act" and the "sanction" are expecting too much. Sanctions, in the sense that they are used by the EU and the United States, are punishment of future behaviors for past behaviors. When applied to something like a country, there is no requirement that the sanctioned entity participated in the past behavior, only that it might facilitate the future behavior; which is itself not necessarily correlated to the past behavior. I know some of you have objected to this interpretation because it may not seem intuitively fair. I am only trying to inform you of how they are, in practice, used; and thus, how we should think of them in terms of this question. Here's hopefully a clarifying example. The past bad behavior was the Russian annexation of Crimea. The sanctions were levied against "a group of about a dozen Russian business leaders or influential figures." The past behavior is not, unless coincidentally, correlated to the sanctioned behavior.
http://www.dw.com/en/sanctioned-russians-get-itchy-feet/a-18708446 To keep insisting that a specific "cyber sanction" is required misses the point of how sanctions are employed. The "cyber" bit of any "cyber sanction" construction is already done. It's found in the Findings portion of the recent Law signed by Obama. All the findings, taken together, comprise what the sanctions are "in response to." So any sanction, whether directed to a target that facilitates money-laundering, or that enables the importation of luxury goods, or that does bad cyber stuff (coincidentally), or whatever, would be a sanction imposed "in response to" a cyber-attack (among the other enumerated things). [Edit: It's easy to get ones head around "the annexation of Crimea" as a name for a whole bunch of sub-activities. The recent Law has an equivalent name for the set of sub-activities being responded to. It is termed "the crisis." Maybe they could have called in something more descriptive. But from a logical perspective, it is the same thing: it collects the instances of bad behaviors into a set. And it is the set that is being responded to.]

My understanding is that the bill won't automatically initiate sanctions when passed, but that the president will now be mandated to investigate sanction-able actions, designate North Korean persons in violation, and report to Congress (within 180 days of the bill being passed) of his efforts to enforce the bill. SEC. 102. INVESTIGATIONS.
(a) Initiation.—The President shall initiate an investigation into the possible designation of a person under section 104(a) upon receipt by the President of credible information indicating that such person has engaged in conduct described in section 104(a). SEC. 103. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.
(a) Presidential Briefings To Congress.—Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, and periodically thereafter, the President shall provide a briefing to the appropriate congressional committees on efforts to implement this Act. Also very important to the question: the bill only mentions "any person" under "designations of persons." Therefore, it looks like the bill applies only to individual people, rather than the North Korean "country" as a whole. And this makes sense since country specific sanctions are normally imposed by the U.S. Congress itself. SEC. 104. DESIGNATION OF PERSONS.
(a) Mandatory Designations.—Except as provided in section 208, the President shall designate under this subsection any person that the President determines (2) EFFECT OF DESIGNATION.—With respect to any person designated under this subsection, the President may— (A) apply the sanctions described in section 204, 205(c), or 206 to the person to the same extent and in the same manner as if the person were designated under subsection (a); (4) DESIGNATED PERSON.—The term “designated person” means a person designated under subsection (a) or (b) of section 104 for purposes of applying 1 or more of the sanctions described in title I or II with respect to the person.

President unlikely to veto based on wiki / constitution website : If he specifically rejects the bill, called a veto, the bill returns to Congress. There it is voted on again, and if both houses of Congress pass the bill again, but this time by a two-thirds majority, then the bill becomes law without the President's signature. This is called "overriding a veto," and is difficult to do because of the two-thirds majority requirement.   Comment : Given the 408 to 2 and 98 to 0 this is just going to look stupid.  Then if he goes with let's ignore it.... From wiki / constitution website: President can sit on the bill, taking no action on it at all. If the President takes no action at all, and ten days passes (not including Sundays), the bill becomes law without the President's signature. However, if the Congress has adjourned before the ten days passes and without a Presidential signature, the bill fails. This is known as a pocket veto

- The Government of North Korea has provided technical support and conducted destructive and coercive cyberattacks, including against Sony Pictures Entertainment and other United States persons. The bill is in response to a crisis which includes two cyber attacks; so the "in response to" bit seems satisfied. 2) We're left with the "impose sanctions on" bit. It doesn't seem that any specific sanction would need to be tied to a specific cyber act or cyber actor, because the way the bill is written it says that: "We're going to respond to this entire list of bad things you've done (the "crisis" you've caused), and sanction you in a whole bunch of ways." That is, the set of sanctions is in response to the set of bad things done, so any sanction imposed is in response to the entire set of bad things. A sanction is imposed ON an activity and AGAINST a (set of) behavior(s). With this bill, there is no specific sanction to specific bad thing correlation; just a set of sanctions to a set of bad things correlation. Therefore, any sanction should do. This is clearly exemplified by the sanction on luxury goods. The sanctions are imposed on (any) X against all Y (the list of bad behaviors). The targeting of sanctions within the bill is the methodology for developing the set X only, it does not establish a requirement that set X and behaviors Y items are correlated; although in most instances they are related. Any sanction imposed under this bill, whether it be on luxury goods, financial transactions, etc., will be a response to the entire list of bad things (which includes two specific cyber attacks).  3) There is the detail of actual imposition, which requires that "the President shall designate under this subsection any person that the President determines" and other actions to actually effectuate the sanctions. Theoretically, I guess, the President might never make such a determination (for any sanction whatsoever). [Edit: Sony Hackers Alive and Well ( http://www.wired.com/2016/02/evidence-suggests-the-sony-hackers-are-alive-and-well-and-still-hacking/ )]

Bumping up a bit, but staying on the unlikely side. The central dilemma here is, once again, that the wording of the question is unclear.  I am reading it to mean sanctions on another state as such, not just on some of its people or organizations; and that the sanctions have to be specifically for "a cyber attack or cyber espionage."  There are several possible ambiguities here, but the big one for me is whether sanctions on a state-owned enterprise would count as sanctions on the "country"; presumably sanctions on an agency of the national government as such (for example, an army unit) would.   I have read the bill, and reading legislation is no more fun than it used to be when I did it for a living.  The bill requires the president to sanction "persons" that the president finds have done some stuff, which would under the other definitions include the offenses in this Q.   "Persons" are individuals or entities as defined by the secretaries of state and treasury;  this could but does not necessarily include national governments.  Frankly it is improbable that the definition will include national governments, because various provisions of the bill might then require the president to sanction China, probably Russia, and maybe even South Korea.   Given that cybercrimes are particularly difficult to attribute definitively to a source, and that the president and two of his cabinet members are the ones who make the findings, it is much more likely that the sanctions will be imposed (a) for something other than cyberstuff; and (b) at least initially on individuals and firms, perhaps from other nations as well as North Korea, at least some of which will be state-owned enterprises (but again, probably not for cybermischief).

Number 1:
Cyber Security
The rise of smart devices and the Internet of Things (IoT) will lead to further opportunities for hackers to gain access to personal information. On the flip side, the IC will be able to use the IoT for "identification, surveillance, monitoring, location tracking, and targeting for recruitment."
An increasing reliance on "Narrow AI" systems, that perform specialized tasks, can both increase efficiency but leave systems open to disruption. Overreliance on these systems, or a lack of securing them properly, could lead to "disruptive or deceptive tactics." As an example, stock market fluctuations have happened due to automated trading systems taking in false data, Clapper notes.
Hackers and foreign military cyber actors will seek to exploit the integrity of networked and online information. This runs the gamut from modifying and transmitting false data to public utilities and market firms, to implanting false information on online media. 
Foreign nations are increasingly buying and exploiting aggregated online personal data tp "inform a variety of counterintelligence operations." 
There is still little impetus for countries to restrain themselves in cyber operations. "Many actors remain undeterred from conducting reconnaissance, espionage, and even attacks in cyberspace because of the relatively low costs of entry, the perceived payoff, and the lack of significant consequences." 
Principal threats: Russia, China, Iran, North Korea, and nonstate actors.  Statement for the Record Worldwide Threat Assessment of the US Intelligence Community Senate Armed Services Committee

I Modeled this problem as a poisson process with mean cyber sanction arrivals of 1 in 5 years for USA, 1 in 10 years for each of Germany, France, and Canada, and 1 in 10 years for others combined for an overall average arrival rate of 6 sanction events in 10 years. Using the poisson model, the probability of 1 or more sanction events this year is 1-exp(-0.6*(days left in year/366)). I don't have a strong basis for my mean arrival rate estimates since there's not a long history of cyber sanctions. For comparison, if I chose 1 in 3 years for the USA, and 1 in 5 years for each of Germany, France, Canada, and other, then the probability of cyber sanctions would jump to 52%. [NOTE: wave arms wildly w.r.t independence assumptions of the poisson model]

The legal framework to pursue sanctions has been initiated in the EU and NA.  With regard to the United States, more work remains to give substance to the law. On December 31, 2015, the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) promulgated regulations for the cyber-related sanctions program (31 C.F.R Part 578).  The regulations issued in boilerplate form have yet to be fleshed out with such details as specific definitions and interpretative guidance.  
http://www.natlawreview.com/article/boilerplate-cyber-sanctions-regulations-portend-coming-actions There also appears to be mounting political pressure to seek actionable responses against cyber threats.  As pointed out in the following article, Executive Order 1367 issued by President Obama in January 2015 provides for affiliation-based sanctions rather than conduct-based sanctions.
http://www.heritage.org/research/testimony/moving-beyond-timid-incrementalism-time-to-fully-implement-us-laws-on-north-korea#_ftn10 The full testimony before the US House of Representatives, House Committee on Foreign Affairs:  https://foreignaffairs.house.gov/hearing/subcommittee-hearing-us-response-north-korea-s-nuclear-provocations The question that arises in my mind is:  Will this be a fast process pushed through by the Executive Branch or a slower one driven by the Legislative Branch?  Or perhaps, the more appropriate question is whether the Obama administration has the strategic understanding and the requisite resolve to pursue this matter?

The key point in this question is the imposition of sanctions. There will most likely be cyber attacks and cyber espionage, there may even be threats of sanctions in response. The problem is that it is fiendishly fraught to assign blame to a state for one of these attacks. The nature of cyber attacks means that the responsible party is obscured. So the first thing we would need to see this year is a significant cyber attack that warrants state-level sanctions. As soon as it happens (I'd give it 30% chance in the next 12 months), the clock is then ticking for the investigation to start and conclude within the calendar year. Most likely this investigation would take several months, and I'm willing to predict that it would take more than 6 months, and 80% chance a year or longer. Then there would be a lot of political bluster and posturing before imposition of sanctions; might take a week to two months maybe? So with an attack needing to occur in the first half of the year for a low chance for a conclusion and imposition of sanctions within 2016, I give the overall chance of this a low score.
Rather unlikely since tracing this kind of attack reliably is still problematic and losses usually are higher than potential gains.

Was the Cyber Attack on a Dam in New York an Armed Attack?
https://www.justsecurity.org/28720/cyber-attack-dam-armed-attack/ It is clear there is an effort to differentiate, at least, Stuxnet-class type cyber attacks. "The eight factors identified by the [International Group of Experts] are severity, immediacy, directness, invasiveness, measurability, military character, state involvement, and presumptive legality." Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Warfare
https://ccdcoe.org/research.html [Edit: I can foresee this entire area (Cyber Warfare Law) becoming a major fiasco in a decade or so. There is, apparently, an attempt to explain a new phenomenon in terms of old concepts (e.g., "armed attack"). The nuances of cyber and information warfare, and their interrelationship, are obviously insufficiently understood and underappreciated. By using old concepts they are creating windows of vulnerabilities in which information operations can still take place that are as, or more, harmful than any kinetic operation one might ever imagine. As the sophistication of these operations become revealed over time, they will wish they had not boxed themselves in by conceptualizing the problem using yesterday's concepts. For example: If I degrade your capability by convincing you to disarm, did I commit an armed attack? "Armed attack" is a wholly inappropriate notion in which to seek to understand information operations that can be disassociated in space, time, and context (not even mentioning the variety of other ways they can be obfuscated); and are seamlessly co-joined in an ensemble of other operations. If our military elite are using notions like "armed attack" to understand cyber and information operations, we are in deep, deep trouble.]

Mr. Obama promised a “proportional” response, but a year later he has failed to follow through. That leaves America’s cybersecurity and fundamental freedoms vulnerable. One year ago, Mr. Obama signed a broad executive order authorizing the U.S. Treasury Department to freeze any assets of North Korea’s government, ruling party, officials and third-country enablers. But the order applies only to persons and entities designated by the administration. A year later, the administration has designated just 18 targets under this order, mostly low-level arms dealers and entities whose assets were already frozen. The administration has yet to freeze the assets of Kim Jong Un or any of his top deputies, who are believed to have billions of dollars in European and Chinese banks. Nor has it frozen the assets of the North Korean-owned Chilbosan Hotel in downtown Shenyang, China, from which hackers carried out cyberattacks for years. The U.S. State Department has ignored bipartisan calls from Congress to designate North Korea as a state sponsor of terrorism. It refuses to acknowledge multiple U.S. federal-court decisions finding that North Korea has sponsored acts of international terrorism, including the kidnapping of a U.S. permanent resident who is believed to have died in North Korean custody. It ignored Pyongyang’s multiple arms shipments to terrorists and its dispatch of clandestine agents to assassinate human-rights activists and dissidents abroad.

I think the term “Cyber Attack” s a bit too vague. There are different types of cyber-ofenses:
Cyber-attack is any type of offensive maneuver employed by individuals or whole organizations that targets computer information systems, infrastructures, computer networks, and/or personal computer devices by various means of malicious acts usually originating from an anonymous source that either steals, alters, or destroys a specified target by hacking into a susceptible system. This type of attack can be perpetrate by a group of teens with too much free time; by professional hackers working on their own or for a country; or by legitimate countries.
Cyber spying, or cyber espionage, is the act or practice of obtaining secrets without the permission of the holder of the information (personal, sensitive, proprietary or of classified nature), from individuals, competitors, rivals, groups, governments and enemies for personal, economic, political or military advantage. CE, well almost every country does it, In fact in September 2015, the United States and China agreed not to allow parties in their nations to cyberspy on each other for commercial gain, but did not prohibit government spying.
Cyber-terrorism is “the use of computer network tools to shut down critical national infrastructures (such as energy, transportation, government operations) or to coerce or intimidate a government or civilian population. CT is the most dangerous one.
We could split hairs even more than that, but it should suffice for now. PLAYERS: The two predominant players are China’s cyber capabilities compared to United States’ capabilities. There are many other state and non-state actors involved in cyberwarfare, such as Russia, Iran, Iraq, and Al Qaeda; but China and the U.S. are leading the foreground in cyberwarfare capabilities.
SANCTIONS: In response to recent cyber-attacks on April 1, 2015 President Obama issued an Executive Order establishing the first-ever economic sanctions. The Executive Order will impact individuals and entities (“designees”) responsible for cyber-attacks that threaten the national security, foreign policy, economic health, or financial stability of the US. Specifically, the Executive Order authorizes the Treasury Department to freeze designees’ assets.

Two factors which makes this unlikely
1) The difficulty in determining the true origin of cyber attacks has been an issue for years. 
2) Imposing sanctions for a cyber attack would be a precedent setting move for the NA/EU countries which would likely cause them to proceed cautiously.  That said, if the transgression was low-enough (unlikely given the nature of what cyber attacks aim to steal/disrupt) there is some chance that limited sanctions are imposed (diplomatic, etc.)

There are two "outside view" variables I think we can use here:
1) How many cyber-attacks this year were linked or blamed on a state actor?
2) How many obvious transgressions similar to cyber attacks led to sanctions? 1)  There were very few cyber-attacks directly linked to a state actor by a EU state or the US, with the exception of the North Korea "Interview" attacks.  While there were many attacks linked to individuals within countries, we still very rarely see countries blamed.  With that, reduction to 5% 2) In terms of which led to cyber-attacks, we're still only on the interview.  So, remains at 5% In terms of the inside view, the countries most at risk are China, Russia, and Iran.  Of the three, Russia is the obvious target: China and Iran are both experiencing a softening in relations, although this might be affected by how China behaves in the future.  While China has previously been actively threatened (http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/17/us/politics/obama-hints-at-sanctions-against-china-over-cyberattacks.html), I think that threat has now passed.  As such, staying at 5% for now. Potential Future Factors:
1) state being linked to major cyber-attack
2) China and Russia becoming more belligerent
3) Further threats to China/evidence of Chinese cyber-attacks on US targets

Major powers all recognise the potential threat of cyber attack and espionage, and it can be confidently stated that all are playing in this space too (e.g. Merkel NSA phone scandal).  However, general responses to foreign intelligence activities amounts to sabre-rattling, or general demonstrative response.  The Australian Bureau of Meteorology (BoM) was allegedly recently subjected to an attack by Chinese hackers.  (It has been hypothesised that this was to breach Defence system to which the BoM mainframe is linked.)  No overt government response.  Handful of unnamed sources stating that it was the Chinese (i.e. the "we know it was you what did it!" approach).  Sanctions, in contrast, are a substantial step up the retaliation ladder.  In addition it would likely be difficult to publicly produce evidence to support a claim of responsibility, and even potentially detrimental to a country's own cyber intelligence activities (that is, revealing what you know about what was done may highlight particular strengths and weaknesses of your e-defenses).

I am really struggling with this question. Although a framework for sanctions which result from cyber attacks is not clear, I nevertheless believe that some named entity will put together some claim of leveling sanctions against some country in response to malicious cyber activity within the time horizon. Further, I do not believe GJ has demonstrated the inclination or the capacity to properly vet the accuracy of such a claim; reserving for itself an arbitrary "GJ fudge factor." applied retroactively at whim if necessary. I am, therefore, changing my forecast to the positive side.

I am still trying to work out what a country-specific sanction (as opposed to an individual or corporate sanction) would look like. One possibility might be that it would be a ban of an entire set or class of individual or corporate types originating from within a particular country based on product or service. For example, as with the Russian reverse-sanction-sanction of banning importation of food categories from selected countries. Would a ban in the United States on the importation of any rug made in Iran be a sanction on Iran or the carpet-makers? Provided the ban is universal ("all carpets from X") I think we could say it was a sanction against X, not just the carpet-makers. So, what universal-type bans would be an appropriate response for a cyber-attack? There's also a difference between export and import bans. They may have comparable symbolism, but export bans are more difficult to enforce. Further, there is also consideration of the specific nature of the economic trade existing between the two relevant nations. Sanctions on the importation of product A from country X might be quite strong, if the export of product A by country X is meaningful. So, in particular circumstances, tying matchsticks or coconuts to cyber-attacks might not be far-fetched at all. Bans on imports also usually incur some cost to the importer. So sanctions, via bans, are a rich area with a lot of flexibility ranging over symbolism to economic effects. If cyber warfare continues as it has, no doubt such cyber-sanctions are to follow. Perhaps there is a joint NSA, Treasury, State department working group within the U.S. actively developing a framework for these now. At this point, however, I haven't caught wind of any such framework. There is also the complication that cyber-warfare is handled within the military command structure, so an integrated economic response might be out of the realm of their expertise, and not even a part of their solution domain. I suppose it boils down to detection and response.  Will an event of sufficient magnitude occur?  Will we trace it back to a state actor?  What is the appropriate response? One stumbling block to resolving this question a “Yes” is tracing back to source.  The perception is that the bad actors can hide behind proxies, either willing or unwilling.  Yet, is it astute to think that a variety of surveillance techniques are applied, not limited to communications, but to also include examination of money flow (Bitcoin, for instance), movement of components, interaction between key people, etc.?  Even if a non-state actor is traced as the source, who provided funding, intelligence, etc. in support of a particular purpose?

Cyber attacks will certainly occur, but sanctions are a very unlikely response. Firstly, it is very difficult to prove the source of attacks. Secondly, sanctions require a fair amount of international consensus. Thirdly, it is worth keeping in mind that the U.S. and EU probably undertake similar actions themselves. Finally even if cyber attacks did prompt some sanctions in the future, the formal justification for them will probably be given as something else (human rights etc) thereby preventing a YES outcome to this question.
